title: Alf Freeman (footballer, born 1920)
text:
Alfred Freeman (2 January 1920 – February 2006) was an English <a href="association%20football">footballer</a> who played as an <a href="inside-forward">inside-forward</a> for <a href="Southampton%20F.C.">Southampton</a> and <a href="Crystal%20Palace%20F.C.">Crystal Palace</a> in the late 1940s.
Football career.
Freeman was born in <a href="Bethnal%20Green">Bethnal Green</a> and joined <a href="Tottenham%20Hotspur%20F.C.">Tottenham Hotspur</a> as a trainee in 1939 but, before he could establish himself, the outbreak of the <a href="World%20War%20II">Second World War</a> brought normal football to a temporary halt.
He enlisted with the <a href="Duke%20of%20Cornwall%27s%20Light%20Infantry">Duke of Cornwall's Light Infantry</a> and saw service in <a href="Invasion%20of%20Normandy">Normandy</a>. While playing football for the army, he met <a href="Alf%20Ramsey">Alf Ramsey</a> and the two became good friends. In his autobiography, "Talking Football" published in 1952, Ramsey credits Freeman with encouraging him to "think tactically" – while this advice may have helped Ramsey to success in his future career as manager of <a href="Ipswich%20Town%20F.C.">Ipswich Town</a> and <a href="England%20national%20football%20team">England</a>, Freeman's career was not so successful.
Freeman joined <a href="Southampton%20F.C.">Southampton</a> in November 1943, while continuing to serve with his army regiment. At Southampton, he was re-united with his friend, Alf Ramsey, who had signed for the club shortly before, and the two shared accommodation. Although registered as a Southampton player from November 1943, he made only one appearance in a wartime league match and it was not until the summer of 1946 that he was able to take up football full-time, having guested for <a href="Sunderland%20A.F.C.">Sunderland</a> in the meantime.
Freeman made his professional debut in the Southampton reserves on 31 August 1946, followed by his first-team debut four days later at <a href="inside-right">inside-right</a> in the opening match of <a href="1946%E2%80%9347%20in%20English%20football">the 1946–47 season</a>, a <a href="Football%20League%20Second%20Division">Football League Second Division</a> match at <a href="Swansea%20Town%20F.C.">Swansea Town</a>. Freeman was used mainly as cover for <a href="Ted%20Bates%20%28footballer%29">Ted Bates</a>, who was frequently unavailable while completing his military service, and missed the next two league matches before returning in place of Bates, scoring twice in a 5–2 victory over <a href="Nottingham%20Forest%20F.C.">Nottingham Forest</a> on 14 September. Despite this, Freeman lost his place to Bates after the next match and played only seven first-team matches in 1946–47.
Having made 21 reserve-team appearances (scoring eight goals) in 1946–47, Freeman spent the entire 1947–48 season in the reserves, with the newly signed <a href="George%20Curtis%20%28footballer%20born%201919%29">George Curtis</a> now the first-team inside-right. Freeman made 33 appearances for the reserves in 1947–48, scoring seven goals, and was released at the end of the season.
In August 1948, he joined <a href="Crystal%20Palace%20F.C.">Crystal Palace</a>, for whom he made two first-team appearances, including one in the <a href="Football%20League%20Third%20Division%20South">Football League Third Division South</a> against <a href="Reading%20F.C.">Reading</a>. Despite Palace finishing at the bottom of the <a href="1948%E2%80%9349%20in%20English%20football%23Third%20Division%20South">league</a>, Freeman was unable to break into the side and was transferred to Reading in the summer of 1949. He made no first-team appearances for Reading and retired the following year.
Later career.
Freeman went into business, manufacturing cardboard cartons and lived in <a href="Hendon">Hendon</a> from where he regularly attended matches at both <a href="White%20Hart%20Lane">White Hart Lane</a> and <a href="Arsenal%20Stadium">Highbury</a>.
